name: Dice Snake
description: It has a robust body, small head, and gray-brown, reddish-brown, or olive coloration with black and yellow spots on its back. It differs from vipers not only by lacking a zigzag pattern but also by its prominent, protruding eyes with round pupils. It exhibits strong sexual dimorphism—males are small and slender, while females tend to be stout and measure around one meter.
spread_note: Central to southeastern Europe, northeastern Africa, eastward through southern Russia to Central Asia and China
image_alt: Dice Snake, photo: Prague Zoo Archive
reproduction: The female lays 5–35 eggs, incubation lasts 6–7 weeks.
attractions: It is tied to water but chooses elevated dry slopes for hibernation. It dives for prey and brings it to shore. It spends much time basking, preferring branches overhanging water.
breeding: The hunting territories of dice snakes in the zoo lie below a slope by the river or millrace, but they spend most of their lives on the rocky slope where they hibernate.
